sn22.86:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
sn22.86:4.2: Now at that time Venerable Anurādha was staying not far from the Buddha in a wilderness hut.
sn22.86:4.3: Then several wanderers who follow other paths went up to Venerable Anurādha
sn22.86:4.5: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side
sn22.86:4.7: “Reverend Anurādha, when a Realized One is describing a Realized One—a supreme person, highest of people, who has reached the highest point—they describe them in these four ways:
sn22.86:4.8: After death, a Realized One exists, or doesn’t exist, or both exists and doesn’t exist, or neither exists nor doesn’t exist.”
sn22.86:5.1: When they said this, Venerable Anurādha said to those wanderers:
sn22.86:5.2: “Reverends, when a Realized One is describing a Realized One—a supreme person, highest of people, who has reached the highest point—they describe them other than these four ways:
sn22.86:5.3: After death, a Realized One exists, or doesn’t exist, or both exists and doesn’t exist, or neither exists nor doesn’t exist.”
sn22.86:5.4: When he said this, the wanderers said to him:
sn22.86:5.5: “This mendicant must be junior, recently gone forth, or else a foolish, incompetent senior mendicant.”
sn22.86:5.6: Then, after rebuking Venerable Anurādha by calling him “junior” and “foolish”, the wanderers got up from their seat and left.
sn22.86:6.1: Soon after they had left, Anurādha thought:
sn22.86:6.2: “If those wanderers were to inquire further,
sn22.86:6.3: how should I answer them so as to repeat what the Buddha has said, and not misrepresent him with an untruth? How should I explain in line with his teaching, so that there would be no legitimate grounds for rebuke and criticism?”
sn22.86:7.1: Then Venerable Anurādha went up to the Buddha,
sn22.86:7.2: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn22.86:7.3: and told him all that had happened.
sn22.86:10.1: “What do you think, Anurādha? Is form permanent or impermanent?”
sn22.86:10.3: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn22.86:10.5: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:
sn22.86:10.6: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn22.86:10.15: They understand: ‘… there is no return to any state of existence.’”
sn22.86:11.1: “What do you think, Anurādha? Do you regard the Realized One as form?”
sn22.86:11.3: “Do you regard the Realized One as feeling …
sn22.86:12.1: “What do you think, Anurādha? Do you regard the Realized One as in form?”
sn22.86:12.3: “Or do you regard the Realized One as distinct from form?”
sn22.86:12.5: “Do you regard the Realized One as in feeling …
sn22.86:13.1: “What do you think, Anurādha? Do you regard the Realized One as possessing form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness?”
sn22.86:14.1: “What do you think, Anurādha? Do you regard the Realized One as one who is without form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness?”
sn22.86:15.1: “In that case, Anurādha, since you don’t acknowledge the Realized One as a genuine fact in the present life, is it appropriate to declare:
sn22.86:15.2: ‘Reverends, when a Realized One is describing a Realized One—a supreme person, highest of people, who has reached the highest point—they describe them other than these four ways:
sn22.86:15.3: After death, a Realized One exists, or doesn’t exist, or both exists and doesn’t exist, or neither exists nor doesn’t exist’?”
sn22.86:16.2: In the past, as today, all I describe is suffering and the cessation of suffering.”
